author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Summer’s Unofficial Start
description: It’s Memorial Day Weekend, the start of summer, ready or not.
content: When I picture time passing, I think of a calendar — specifically, a full-year calendar printed on one page, the sort that a bank or a restaurant might hand out as a freebie, emblazoned with its logo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, May 20-26
description: Were you “blocked” from reaching Queen Bee?
content: This week, tinhorn — used to describe someone pretending to have money and influence — was the word least found by players of Spelling Bee, while blocked was the word most found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffanie Graham
title: How Police Violence Weighs on Black Americans
description: We spoke to more than 100 people about the psychological strain from repeated reports of police brutality.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Fixer-Uppers With Waterfront Views: The U.S. Is Unloading Lighthouses
description: The General Services Administration said it was offering six to nonprofits or government agencies that promise to maintain them, and selling four others at auction.
content: Looking for a place with waterfront views? The government might have a deal for you.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 27, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 27, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about the capture of a fugitive in Rwanda misstated the name of a branch of the Rwandan military that has been disbanded. It was the Armed Forces of Rwanda, not the Rwanda Defense Force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Has ‘Gig Work’ Become a Dirty Word?
description: If work for companies like Uber and Lyft once carried some appeal for offering flexibility, the kind of labor it has come to represent is now used by some as shorthand for a raw deal.
content: When more than 11,000 film and television writers in the Writers Guild of America union went on strike this month, they called out deteriorating working conditions, criticized unfair pay and said they worried about losing their jobs to artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canada Needs to Hurry on A.I. Oversight, Experts Warn
description: The measures of an artificial intelligence bill won’t go into effect until 2025. For some, that’s too late.
content: Two of the three godfathers of A.I. are professors based in Canada. One of them, Geoffrey Hinton of the University of Toronto, recently left his job at Google in order to speak more frankly about the risks of artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: More and More Teenagers Are Coming to School High, Teachers Say
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 27, 2023.
content: “It really feels like this unstoppable tide that we’re futilely trying to suppress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Paul Sonne
title: Barely Noting War in Public, Putin Acts Like Time Is on His Side
description: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia looks like a commander in absentia, treating the war in Ukraine as unfortunate but distant. His options have narrowed, but he is still betting on outlasting his foes.
content: Pro-Ukrainian fighters stormed across the border into southwestern Russia this past week, prompting two days of the heaviest fighting on Russian territory in 15 months of war. Yet President Vladimir V. Putin, in public, ignored the matter entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: It’s ‘More Expensive to Live,’ and Workers Are Cracing 401(k)s for Help
description: Retirement plan administrators are noting an uptick in hardship withdrawals. But taking that money out can harm your future financial security.
content: More Americans are raiding their retirement accounts as the cost of living climbs, and experts predict that the number of workers drawing on their 401(k)s to pay for financial emergencies  may increase due to a confluence of factors, like new provisions that make withdrawals easier and high inflation that is straining household budgets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Paul Brammer
title: What’s the Deal With Men?
description: In his new essay collection, “The Male Gazed,” the writer and film critic Manuel Betancourt explores society’s portrayals of masculinity.
content: Toxic masculinity. Fragile masculinity. Like most pop-sociological truisms that gain traction on social media, these are great buzzwords but they fail to grapple with nuance. A slogan isn’t a thesis, of course, but I’ve always found these terms to be simplistic substitutions for more interesting conversations. Yes, masculinity, which is often a patriarchal institution that metes out seemingly impossible social expectations for men and boys, has no shortage of problems. But what about its appeal? What’s so captivating about it to so many people, including many who are victims of its overbearing norms?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Sarah Kessler and Bernhard Warner
title: Why Do Almost Half of Americans Leave Paid Time Off on the Table?
description: In a recent Pew survey, top reasons included worry about falling behind and fear of being fired. DealBook wants to know yours.
content: Summer vacation season is here. But if you’re like a surprising number of Americans, you’re probably leaving some paid time off on the table. Among workers whose employer offers paid vacation or leave, 46 percent said they typically took less time off than was offered, a recent Pew survey found. Here’s why:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel, Maya King, Kurtis Lee and Shawn Hubler
title: Reparations Are a Financial Quandary. For Democrats, They’re a Political One, Too.
description: Republicans have criticized recent estimates of what Black Americans are owed in reparations. But for Democrats, they pose deeper problems for a party eager to retain the allegiance of Black voters.
content: What should Americans pay for the legacy of slavery and a century of Jim Crow segregation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Rudnick
title: What Would Happen if a Robot Tried to Write ‘Law & Order’?
description: Some Hollywood producers dream of a future where chatbots do the writing. Be careful what you wish for.
content: As the strike by unions representing thousands of film and TV writers approaches its second month, the role that A.I. might play in writing scripts remains one of the biggest issues. While the Writers Guild of America has expressed a willingness to work with A.I. as a tool, some producers are dreaming bigger: They want to replace humans with chatbots. What might A.I.-written scripts look like? Here’s a guess:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: The Humble ‘Sticky Pad’ Keeping N.B.A. Sneakers on the Court
description: Players across the league have long relied on a pad of translucent sheets of adhesive known as a Slipp-Nott to ensure they have enough traction during games.
content: Gabe Vincent and Max Strus of the Miami Heat sat in their side-by-side lockers at Madison Square Garden an hour before a game against the Knicks. Strus was eating vegetables and rice, and Vincent was changing into his uniform after practicing shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Stanley Engerman, Revisionist Scholar of Slavery, Dies at 87
description: His two-volume study, written with Robert W. Fogel, used data to challenge commonly held ideas about American slavery, including that it was unprofitable and inefficient.
content: Stanley Engerman, one of the authors of a deeply researched book that, wading into the fraught history of American slavery, argued that it was a rational, viable economic system and that enslaved Black people were more efficient workers than free white people in the North, died on May 11 in Watertown, Mass. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: What to know about the whistle-blowers who accused Ken Paxton of wrongdoing.
description: Four former employees and allies of the Texas attorney general joined forces to file a lawsuit in 2020.
content: The four men behind the whistle-blower lawsuit that landed the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, in political peril were once employees and allies whom Mr. Paxton handpicked to advance his conservative agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden Administration Announces Indo-Pacific Deal, Clashing With Industry Groups
description: The United States announced a deal to coordinate supply chains with allies, but prominent business groups said the deal fell short on reducing tariffs and other trade barriers.
content: The Biden administration announced Saturday that it had reached an agreement with 13 other countries in the Indo-Pacific region to coordinate supply chains, in an effort to lessen the countries’ dependence on China for critical products and allow them to better weather crises like wars, pandemics and climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon, Dana Rubinstein and Calla Kessler
title: Why New York City’s Lifeguard Shortage Is Even Worse This Year
description: Despite pay increases and efforts to simplify the notoriously difficult swim test, New York’s lifeguard shortage is dire. The city says the lifeguard unions are partly to blame.
content: As New York City’s 14 miles of public beaches open for Memorial Day weekend, the city is confronting its worst lifeguard shortage on record — something officials say is partly the result of a bitter fight between the city and the little-known but extraordinarily powerful unions that represent lifeguards.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Applying D.E.I. to Science
description: Readers react to Pamela Paul’s argument that some diversity efforts have been misguided.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Apartment Is Infested With Bugs. How Do I Make My Landlord Fix It?
description: There are numerous ways you can pressure a landlord to take action. Sometimes it takes using all of them to get a result.
content: Q: I am a senior who has lived quietly in my rent-stabilized Brooklyn apartment for 22 years. For the past three years, my home has been infested with biting gnats. I have disposed of infested possessions — furniture, rugs, clothing, bedding — but the insects continue to bite me throughout the night. My complaints to management have gone unanswered. I paid an exterminator $200, to no avail. Another exterminator said my landlord had to make the request, not me. After I called 311, a city inspector visited my apartment and contacted the landlord, who reported that the problem was resolved. I challenged that, but the case was closed anyway. I opened a new complaint and have yet to get an inspection. What can I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
title: For the Indigenous, Was This Building a Gesture of Reconciliation? Or an Empty Gift?
description: The company chartered centuries ago to found the colony that became part of Canada last year gave a building to the Indigenous that is heavy in symbolism. The move is being criticized by some as hollow.
content: Near the old perfume counters on the ground floor of the Hudson’s Bay department store in Winnipeg, Canada, a trade dripping with symbolism took place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Touches Down in New Jersey
description: The pop megastar’s first of three shows at MetLife Stadium featured an appearance from the rising rapper Ice Spice, a fan-favorite song and loads of sequins.
content: On Friday afternoon, a seemingly endless parade of Taylor Swift fans wearing flowery dresses, sparkly cowboy boots, sequined T-shirts and handmade friendship bracelets made their way to East Rutherford, N.J., turning the vast asphalt parking lot at MetLife Stadium into a pop-up performance space, a fashion runway and a meeting ground for friends, old and new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Is That a Summer House I See? I’ve Missed You, We Should Catch Up.
description: With the unofficial start of summer comes, for some, a scramble to secure a free getaway somewhere.
content: Grace Palumbo, a kindergarten teacher in Denver, has one goal right now: to get access to a beach house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Twitter Shrank Elon Musk and Ron DeSantis
description: Social media can be a trap.
content: If you had told me several months ago, immediately after Elon Musk bought Twitter and Ron DeSantis celebrated a thumping re-election victory, that DeSantis would launch his presidential campaign in conversation with Musk, I would have thought, intriguing: The rightward-trending billionaire whose rockets and cars stand out in an economy dominated by apps and financial instruments meets the Republican politician whose real-world victories contrast with the virtual populism of Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen’s Debt Limit Warnings Went Unheeded, Leaving Her to Face Fallout
description: The Treasury secretary, who considered ways to contain the fallout of a default when she was a Fed official in 2011, had urged Democrats to raise the limit while they still had control of Congress.
content: In the days after November’s midterm elections, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen was feeling upbeat about the fact that Democrats had performed better than expected and maintained control of the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It’s a Treat
description: Samuel Smalley’s debut puzzle makes for a wild ride!
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Friends, I just took a week off from everything, including solving crosswords, and I … could not get anywhere with this grid, even after multiple attempts. Does rust form that quickly? I like to think that this puzzle is just tough as nails, and once I finally got my own claws into it I found it a terrific solve. The many, many trips I took through the clues also allowed me to better appreciate the eccentric wordplay and juxtapositions scattered throughout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
title: Indian Official Who Drained a Reservoir to Retrieve His Phone Is Suspended
description: Rajesh Vishwas, a food inspector, used a diesel pump to empty part of a reservoir where he had lost his smartphone.
content: Say you drop your brand-new smartphone into a reservoir while posing for a selfie during a picnic. Would you consider it lost and buy a replacement, or drain the reservoir to retrieve it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Don’t Kill ‘Frankenstein’ With Real Frankensteins at Large
description: As A.I. grows, this is no time to discard the humanities.
content: WASHINGTON — By the time I took off my mortarboard two weeks ago, my degree in English literature was de trop. Instead of a Master of Arts, I should have gotten a Master of Algorithms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Peter Baker and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden and McCarthy Speak by Phone as They Push to Cement Debt Limit Deal
description: Earlier, a top Republican negotiator said an agreement was “hours or days” away, as an ultraconservative group of lawmakers harshly criticized its emerging contours.
content: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy spoke by telephone on Saturday evening as White House and congressional Republicans worked feverishly to cement a deal to raise the nation’s debt ceiling and avert a fiscal crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: Jane Doe
description: Plus the best of the archive, found in New York Times Audio.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, and exclusive new shows that we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilan Stavans
title: The Newest Immigrants Will Change American Spanish. That’s a Good Thing.
description: Venezuelans are but the latest wave of migrants to invigorate American Spanish.
content: Spanish speakers across the Caribbean exclaim “¡Qué vaina!” when describing ‌an annoyance, a situation or a predicament. But the saying is especially versatile in Venezuelan slang, where it can be used to refer to anything from objects to people — the possibilities are endless. Increasingly, you hear that idiosyncrasy in Ciudad Juárez, ‌Mexico; in Texas and Florida; and even in shelters and schools in New York City as Venezuelan asylum seekers settle in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Ingrid Haebler, Pianist Known for Her Mastery of Mozart, Is Dead
description: In concerts and on dozens of recordings, she applied a delicate touch that critics said set her apart from other performers.
content: Ingrid Haebler, a pianist who drew particular acclaim for her performances and recordings of the works of Mozart, impressing critics while still in her 20s with elegant interpretations that set her apart from other musicians of her day, died on May 14. She was believed to be 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Must Be Pleased With the Way the Republican Race Is Shaping Up
description: It’s 2016 all over again.
content: This week, two candidates officially joined the Republican presidential field: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Trump calls impeachment proceedings against Ken Paxton ‘very unfair.’
description: The former president took to social media to weigh in on the events in Texas.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Saturday that the impeachment proceedings against Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, were unfair and vowed to fight against lawmakers who pursued impeachment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt
title: ‘It’s Time’: Ukraine’s Top Commander Says Counteroffensive Is Imminent
description: A blunt statement, accompanied by a slickly produced video of Ukrainian troops preparing for battle, appeared designed to rally the nation and to spread anxiety among Russian forces.
content: Ukraine’s top military commander signaled on Saturday morning that the nation’s forces were ready to launch their long-anticipated counteroffensive following months of preparations, including recently stepped-up attacks on logistical targets as well as feints and disinformation intended to keep Russian forces on edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Overlooked No More: Sultan Khan, Untrained Chess Player Who Became a Champion
description: He beat some of the world’s top players despite growing up with little access to chess books and not having the same knowledge his rivals possessed.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: An 11-Year-Old Boy Called 911. Police Then Shot Him.
description: Aderrien Murry suffered numerous injuries, including a collapsed lung, lacerated liver and fractured ribs. His family is demanding that the officer who shot him be fired.
content: A family has demanded that a Mississippi police officer be fired after shooting an 11-year-old boy who was trying to follow the officer’s orders after calling 911 for help, a lawyer for the boy’s family said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Starts to Crack Down on Password Sharing
description: The streaming company had said it was looking for ways to increase revenue. And one way was to make more people pay for the service.
content: The great Netflix password crackdown has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: For These Veterans, ‘Free’ Health Care Is a 5-Hour Flight Away
description: Citizens of three Pacific Island nations, eligible to serve in the U.S. military, find it hard to make use of the health benefits they have earned.
content: Ovenny Jermeto was on a combat tour 7,000 miles away from his island home in the Pacific when a bomb blew up his vehicle in the Hindu Kush mountains of Afghanistan. He survived and completed his deployment, but later lost feeling in his right foot and struggled with anxiety and depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Anatomy of a Fall’ Wins the Palme d’Or
description: The French filmmaker Justine Triet becomes the third woman to win the top honor at the Cannes Film Festival.
content: The 76th Cannes Film Festival ended Saturday with the Palme d’Or awarded to “Anatomy of a Fall.” Directed by Justine Triet, this intellectual thriller centers on a woman who is brought to trial after the mysterious death of her husband. Written by Triet and Arthur Harari, the film was an early favorite with critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Lexi Underwood Can Relate to ‘BoJack Horseman’
description: The “Cruel Summer” actor explains why Frank Ocean, ramen and “MJ: The Musical” are among her favorite things.
content: As she was learning the part of Isabella, who she plays on the teen drama “Cruel Summer,” Lexi Underwood asked herself, “What would Pearl do?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Flood-Battered Italian Region May See More Violent and Frequent Storms
description: Experts have linked recent deadly rains in the north of the country to climate change, but decades of urbanization and neglect helped lay the groundwork for a calamity.
content: The floods that submerged the northern Italian region of Emilia-Romagna this month, killing 15 people, leaving thousands homeless and grinding transportation and businesses to a halt, were not one-off events, warn experts, who predict that there are more similar, frequent and violent storms to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Who is Nate Paul, the donor at the center of the case?
description: The real estate developer’s appeal for help from the Texas attorney general is under scrutiny.
content: Much of the alleged misconduct detailed in the articles of impeachment filed against Attorney General Ken Paxton centers on his relationship with a real estate investor, Nate Paul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Rosenblatt
title: I Won a Prize. So What?
description: Prizes feel great. They also don’t change anything.
content: Ah, the magical season of prizes is once again upon us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: What Carmelo Anthony Meant to New York City
description: Anthony, a Brooklyn native, rejuvenated a beleaguered Knicks fan base and embraced the city’s culture, on and off the court.
content: There were many moments that evoked roars inside Madison Square Garden when the Knicks faced the Miami Heat in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference semifinals this month: when Jalen Brunson hit a 3-pointer late in the fourth quarter, prompting a Heat timeout, or any of the five times RJ Barrett sank a 3, sending the Garden’s white-knuckled Knicks fans into a frenzy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: After a Surprise Debut, the Conductor Thomas Guggeis Is Rising Fast
description: Not yet 30, Guggeis already leads a major opera house and has conducted the “Ring” in Berlin. Next up: his arrival at the Metropolitan Opera.
content: Thomas Guggeis was a young repetiteur at the Berlin State Opera five years ago when he was asked a career-changing question: Could he conduct “Salome”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: At West Point Commencement, Kamala Harris Says Military’s Strength Lies in Diversity
description: The vice president’s address to graduates of the U.S. Military Academy came as the armed forces have sought to forge a new identity.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris on Saturday became the first woman to address a graduating class at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, and used the opportunity to extol the diversity of the American armed forces at a time of struggle over the military’s identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Covid Is Coming Back in China; Lockdowns Are Not
description: The authorities say that cases are up, and one doctor estimates that there could soon be 65 million cases a week. But China appears determined to move on.
content: In December, China abruptly abandoned its draconian “Zero Covid” policies, battered by a surge of infections and rising public anger against lockdowns. Half a year on, Covid cases again are on the rise, but this time the nation appears to be determined to press on with normal life as the government focuses on reigniting economic growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: When Your Sexuality Is Against the Law
description: Even in African countries that have decriminalized homosexuality, life is not easy for gay people.
content: I’m traveling in West Africa on my annual win-a-trip journey, a global reporting expedition on which I take a university student to highlight issues that deserve more attention. My winner this year is Maddie Bender, a recent Yale graduate (the pandemic delayed our trip) — and with that, I’m handing the rest of the column over to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg, Michael S. Schmidt and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Missteps and Miscalculations: Inside Fox’s Legal and Business Debacle
description: Fox’s handling of the defamation suit brought by Dominion Voting Systems, which settled for $787.5 million, left many unanswered questions.
content: In August 2021, the Fox Corporation board of directors gathered on the company’s movie studio lot in Los Angeles. Among the topics on the agenda: Dominion Voting Systems’ $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit against its cable news network, Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Student Cannot Wear Sash of Mexican and U.S. Flags at Graduation, Judge Rules
description: A high school senior sued a Colorado school district after she was told she could not wear the sash celebrating her heritage at her commencement ceremony.
content: A federal judge on Friday upheld a decision barring a student from wearing a sash honoring her Mexican American heritage to her graduation ceremony after the high school senior sued her Colorado school district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Sorrentino
title: My Father the Frustrated Artist
description: Domenico Starnone’s novel “The House on Via Gemito” is a searching work of autofiction about a family in postwar Naples.
content: “Marriage,” wrote Cyril Connolly in 1938, “can succeed for an artist only where there is enough money to save him from taking on uncongenial work and a wife who is intelligent and unselfish enough to understand and respect the working of the unfriendly cycle of the creative imagination. … There is no more somber enemy of good art than the pram in the hall.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Steps Up Attacks on Trump, Hitting Him on Crime and Covid
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida vowed to repeal the First Step Act, a Trump-era criminal justice law, if elected president. He called it “basically a jailbreak bill.”
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida escalated his hostilities with former President Donald J. Trump on Friday, arguing that his Republican presidential rival was weak on crime and immigration, and accusing him of ceding critical decision-making during the coronavirus pandemic to Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: U-Haul
description: Chandi Deitmer and Taylor Johnson are here to help us move.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, James Dobbins and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Ken Paxton Is Temporarily Suspended After Texas House Vote
description: The state attorney general and conservative star faces a trial in the Senate.
content: Lawmakers in the Texas House voted on Saturday to impeach Ken Paxton, the state’s Republican attorney general, temporarily removing him from office over charges that he had used his elected position to benefit himself and a campaign donor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Here’s What Happens When Your Lawyer Uses ChatGPT
description: A lawyer representing a man who sued an airline relied on artificial intelligence to help prepare a court filing. It did not go well.
content: The lawsuit began like so many others: A man named Roberto Mata sued the airline Avianca, saying he was injured when a metal serving cart struck his knee during a flight to Kennedy International Airport in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Catching Up With Celebrities in Cannes
description: At a fund-raiser, Coco Rocha, Rebel Wilson and Bebe Rexha revealed the most unglamorous thing about the film festival.
content: The amfAR Gala in Cannes, France, may be the only social event to rival the Met Gala. Held at the sprawling Hôtel du Cap-Eden-Roc during the Cannes Film Festival, the event raises money for AIDS research. As guests were reminded multiple times throughout the evening on May 25, H.I.V. is not extinct (about 38 million people were living with the virus in 2021).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Finding Pain and Nobility in Everyday Americans
description: With a retrospective in Philadelphia, Judith Joy Ross is still seeking to capture a mysterious moment.
content: In a room hung with empathetic black-and-white photographic portraits for her retrospective at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Judith Joy Ross, frail-looking and white-haired, was recently taking pictures for her next series. Posing a guard in front of her old-fashioned wooden view camera, she chattered on in an obscenity-laced monologue about her ineptitude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German Plan Would Ease Path to Citizenship, but Not Without a Fight
description: Months of wrangling over a new law have Germans asking a fundamental question: Are we a country of immigrants?
content: Young, educated and motivated, José Leonardo Cabrera Barroso is just the kind of immigrant the government says Germany needs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: The 20 articles of impeachment against the Texas attorney general.
content: The 20 articles of impeachment against the Texas attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times
